Dear Andy,

You stated:

"You're missing a very important point. The CO2 emitted by plant life annually does totally dwarf the emissions from burning fossil fuels. But plants are taking up a larger amount than is emitted."

This is not entirely correct. Important for the uptake of CO_2 by vegetation are two processes: The tranfer of CO_2 through the stomatas and the CO_2 uptake inside the stomatal cavities. It is rather difficult to quantify these processes.

The stomatal resistance of the foliage, for instance, is a function of the photosynthetically active radiation, the distribution of the leaf area density, the water vapor deficit, the leaf temperature, the soil moisture content, and the ambient CO_2 concentration. The quantification of this stomatal resistance is based on a crude parameterization scheme. It becomes more crude if in a numerical model of the atmosphere like the atmospheric module of a GCM the stomatal resistance for a patchy landscape has to be quantified.

What is the stomatal resistance, for instance, in the case of a GCM grid element of about 60 000 km^2? How can the uptake of CO_2 inside the cavities be quantified in such a case? These questions cannot be answered in a reasonable manner. Any attempt to quantify the uptake of CO_2 by vegetation is mainly guessing using crude parameterization schemes.

Even if someone has 100 bottles of wine in his cellar it does not mean that his consumption of wine does increase.

Best regards

Gerhard

So, according to the piece at Realclimate, “science” is some sort monolithic entity and enterprise, and under its all-encompassing rubric, any and every virtuous episode immediately redounds to the credit of the entire blissfully smug crew. Uh, I don’t think so.--

Of all the cant that infests this miserable discourse, few words shimmer with as much darkly radiant mendacity as the heretofore noble and simple word “science.” Its glorious restlessness has been saddled with the dismal and lying adjective “settled”; worse, it has been yoked to the obvious weasel word “consensus”; and worst of all, some propagandists would have you believe that there is something called “the science.”

Science is not “settled”; it does not proceed through “consensus”; and there is no ideologically convenient entity called “the science,” the existence of which no right-thinking person could possibly deny.

No. Science is not an singular entity or enterprise, but an activity spread across many fields and disciplines, all of which with have *wildly* different standards of what constitutes rigor and what counts as a legitimate result.

The whimsical prognostications of “climate science” should not be compared with serious, well-quantified, disciplines that have yielded successful theories, making innumerable and correct predictions, and all of them drawn from the refining fire of experiment. No. “Climate science” is nothing like that.

Louis Derry has been posting some fantastic stuff, but allow Eli to get back to the point. Actually RayP's point, but one that the bunny thinks he allowed to get lost.

THERE IS NO REASON TO THINK THAT THE PROPER DISCOUNT RATE FOR CO2 CONTAMINATION CONTROL IS POSITIVE.

What does Eli mean? Carbon contamination of the atmosphere, as RayP points out is characterized by enduring and increasing damage to the Earth, and those who inhabit it. While you might use a 3, or 2 or 1% discount rate on the cost of funds for dealing with the harm that pumping CO2 into the atmosphere causes, you also have to recognize that the effect of not dealing with it is cumulative, accelerating and extends far into the future. To be consistent you have to use a negative discount rate for that. The result certainly balances out way lower than +3%, and most likely is negative.

The general rubric for dealing with this goes under the name of the social discount rate, and is not a cost of funds, but an attempt to calculate harms and benefits to future generations to balance against those in this generation.

Using a simplistic financial discount rate as Lomborg does, is as Steve Bloom pointed out on a different question, characteristic of the freakonomics school of argument, where each chapter contains a fundamental sleight-of-hand that requires a degree of expertise to spot. If you miss those, the rest tends to seem eminently reasonable. If you spot it, you can only conclude that the freak was being either dumb, or dishonest. Since the slight of hand is most often subtle, mostly you conclude the freak is being dishonest, but mostly the freak smiles at you and says who me?

What's most telling about this discussion of Mr. Cohen's Op-Ed piece is that people on both sides of the issue are taking what they want from it, and it appears that it was written pecisely for that purpose. An article that appears to support Global Warming while stating that the climate is getting colder is exactly what sells newspapers (or attracts web traffic.) But the article uses our own inexact, non-scientific sense of "colder" or "warmer" weather to imply something that the facts don't support. It especially exploits the fact that most people who are not scientists assume heavier snowfalls MUST occur along with colder weather.
I would like to reiterate the point. Winters in the northern U.S., northern Europe and east Asia have shown an INCREASE in high snowfall events over the last few decades, and this makes sense under the theories about Global Warming. But they are NOT getting colder, and this is supported by factual evidence. By conflating the two, Mr. Cohen gets the attention and satisfaction of people who (against the great majority of climatologists) believe there is no Global Warming. Just as importantly, he talks about the planet clearly getting warmer so that the people who believe in Global Warming look at it as supportive of their views. But the article contains a subtle insistance that winters in the most heavily populated corridors of the U.S., Europe and Asia are getting colder due to Global Warming. As another reader commented here, if that's true than we don't need to care. But that is NOT true, and we do need to care.
The saddest part of this is that the NY Times, the "paper of record", which I have read and admired for over 40 years, is publishing an article that makes incorrect statements stated as fact on an extremely important issue. That doesn't help educate the public about the correct science (the facts) at all.

This thread is premised on the proposition that there are mechanisms by which unusually cold winters are still possible in a warming world.

But we need to take note of the new paper by R.S.Knox and D.H.Douglass, "Recent Energy Balance of Earth", in the International Journal of Geosciences, 2010, Vol.1, no. 3 (November)-in press.

The paper examines the latest data on ocean heat content.

Recall that, because of the vast heat capacity of the oceans compared to the atmosphere, global warming is impossible if ocean heat content is steady or declining.

Allow me to quote from Knox and Douglass: "In summary, we find that estimates of the recent (2003-2008) OHC [ocean heat content] rates of change are preponderantly negative. This does not support the existence of either a large positive radiative imbalance or a "missing energy". "

In other words, since OHC is declining, global warming is not happening at the moment.

Even committed warmistas such as Gavin Schmidt speak, (in private, in Climategate e-mails) of "the current pause" in global warming. And even Lyman et al, authors of "Robust Warming of the Global Upper Ocean" in Nature, Vol. 465, 2010, pp 334-337, admit that OHC rise "flattened out" in 2001-2002 and has not risen since.

There is really no mystery that cold winters accompany a time when ocean heat content is declining.

And there is no need to invent complex, baroque mechanisms by which global warming could produce harsh winters because, at present, by the best available OHC data, global warming appears to be, at the very least, in a "pause", or "flattened out".

No telling how long the current pause in global warming will persist, of course. Some fairly high-powered scientists think it will persist into 2030-2040(Easterbrook, Tsonis, the Russian academicians) but there is no guarantee of any such thing.

If and when global warming resumes, as measured by a clear rise in OHC, then it would be appropriate to work the puzzle on why cold winters would appear in a warming world.

Until then, there is no need to tax the brain to resolve such a contradiction, because the underlying premise of the conundrum-that the world is warming- does not, at present, appear to be operating.
